WEDNESDAY, FEBRUARY 15, 1905.

div.head: OPENING OF PARLIAMENT.
div.p: Yesterday was the opening day of what is generally believed will be the last session of the present British Government, and the Dissolution, which cannot under any circumstances be very much longer delayed, is a subject of anxious interest. To contemplate as beneficial a General Election in the spring, it is necessary to feel pretty sure that the war will yield no untoward developments, no menacing surprise, at about that time. Without a feeling of this kind, how should Mr. Balfour propose to give the country up to the turmoil which is expected of the next General Election? Such an election is not an affair of a day or a week. Between the dismissal of this Parliament and the completion of its successor there would be time enough for things to happen, whether by accident or design. The war bas opened the door to so many possibilities, so many mischances, that the most gitted seer is unable to say in February what may be the outlook in March, nor could there be any surety that an election in April would not be interrupted by some distracting cause of popular infuriation or alarm from abroad. Under our Parliamentary system a General Election may come in the way of such events unavoidably. To put an election in their way as a matter of choice is quite another thing; and only to be justified, in cases of extreme hazard like the present, by reasons of extraordinary weight.. Do any sach reasons exist 1 The Liberal leaders and others may honestly answer-Yes. But, in the first place, they cannot take from Mr. Balfour the responsibility of deciding the matter, and in the next there seems to be a difference of view between himself and them. Almost, though not quite, always they regard the future through the fiscal-lens. Prime Minister. 'He fobs the fiscal leris, and, beyond the 'customary and expected duties of Government, gives but little attention to anything else at present than the course of the war, its consequences and its portents. So we are taught, at any rate, by all that we know of it, of him, and of the nature of things.

But there is much more than this to be said, of course. The risk of being caught in the midst of a General Election by some threatening accident or startling surprise. is a serious consideration, yet not so serious as some others for a man in Mr. Balfour's position. And they are perfectly obvious too. It is plain that he cannot contemplate a Genéral Election in April or at any later time of the year with a confident assurance of success. He may think the chances in his favor; may rely upon being able to increase them greatly as soon as the conflict begins; but yet he must be conscious that he would offer himself for defeat as well as for victory. Unless superseded by very grave events (in which case volunteer dissolution would become impossible), fiscal reform is the question upon which a General Election this year would almost entirely turn. Naturally, all the forces of the Opposition would be employed in making Free Trade c. Protection its chief battle-ground; and we express no opinion of our own in recalling the fact that the best-known judgment in such matters is clear that on this ground the Government would be defeated. That is Mr. Chamberlain's opinion, and he has given friends and foes alike to understand that his proceedings and anticipations are based upon it. It is only quoted here, however, as further justifying the assumption that the Prime Minister, if and when he contemplates a dissolution of Parliament this year, must also contemplate being beaten at the polls as rather more than a possibility.

The Government have, we must confess, used the Recess in a suicidal way. They have brewed much trouble for themselves in Parlia ment. Whatever the outcome of the Com mission of Inquiry may be, the Prime Minister's handling of the affair, in words if not in action, has not aroused entire satisfaction, amongst his supporters. During the Recess the. Artillery Rearmament scandal has been dragged very fully to light. Not content with the damage thus done to their reputation, Ministers-Mr. Balfour and Mr. Arnold-Forsterhave proceeded to make it as irreparable as possible by attempted evasion and a defence. founded on initial delusion. The gross mis. management of our Army and the dangerously chaotic condition in which all the talk of reform has left us has formed the subject. of a remarkable correspondence in a. Unionist organ. And finally, not content with all that, the Government, under the tactless guidance of Mr. Brodrick, in whom past experience might have induced a certain messure of caution, has blundered into the pus blication of their somewhat ungenerously-conducted dispute with Colonel Younghusbandand the publication, even more than the Government's attitude, has, we fear, put the fiuishing touch to the irritation provoked by all the other blunders in the minds of far too many staunch Unionists, "

div.head: THE BRINDISI MAIL
div.p: will be distributed at the G.P.O., Alexandrin, at 7.45 a,m. to morrow.

div.head: THE WHITE STAR
div.p: liner "Romanio" arrived at Alexandria this morning from Boston and Naples with about 150 tourists on board for Cairo.

div.head: ALHAMBRA THEATRE. --
div.p: A gala performance is announced for Friday next in honor of the artistic director of the ballet troupe, Sig. Euzo Longhi.

div.head: Suez Canal.
div.p: On the 9th and 10th inst. 25 vessels passed through the Canal, 20 of which were British, 1 Dutch, 1 German, 1 Austrian, 2 French. The receipts for the two days were frs, 703,792.82, making the total from 1st inst. frs. 3,761,733.51.

div.head: ORIENTAL CONGRESS. --
div.p: The Egyptian Government has decided to take part in the Congress of Orientalists which will be held at Algiers during the present year, and Sultan Effendi Muhamed, Abdul Aziz Jaoniche, and Sheikh Hamed wil represent Eypt at the Congress.

div.head: EGYPT AT ST. LOUIS.---
div.p: Mr. John Wanamaker, of Philadelphia, has purchased half of the Egyptian authropological exhibit at the World's Fair, St. Louis, which included an ancient sarcophagus and a mummy (200 B.C.), for the Philadelphia diusuun. The price paid for the exhibits aggregated about $70,000.

div.head: CAKE WALK COMPETITION. -
div.p: One of the chief incidents of the forthcoming Cairo 'Tradesmen's Ball is to be the grand cake walk competitiou. It is expected that this competition will actract a number of entries. A valuable prize is to be presented to the most perfect "cake walker."

div.head: CHARITY LOTTERY.
div.p: Mime de la Boulimiere has received a beautiful Sèvres vase from the President of the French Republic for the Lottery which she has organised in aid of the home for the aged, the orphanages, and the dispensaries in Old Cairo. The lottery is to be drawn at the French Agency to-day.

div.head: OUR VISITORS.
div.p: Every day our newspapers give a list of the illustrous guests who are attracted to Egypt by the delightful climate. Several of these devole part of their leisure to the study of French, English, German, Arabie, etc., at the Berlitz schools, at Alexandria, and especially at Cairo, where there is very much stir. The renown of the system is universal, and besides there is the advantage of the transier tickets, which allow the tourist to continue in Europe or America the lessons begun in Cairo or Alexandria.

div.head: A GUIDE TO EGYPT.
div.p: To the capable hands of Dr. Wallis Budgy, of the British Museum, has been entrusted the task of writing Cook's Handbook of Egypt and the Sudan" (Thoma Cook and Son), and he has succeeded in making a subject, interesting enough in itself, still mune interesting by the Wealth of knowledge brought to bear on it. Profusely illustrateu with maps and sketches, the work enables even the stay-at-home traveller to almost believe himself in the land of the Pharaohs, while to those fortunate enough to Visit the East it is absolutely indispensable.

div.head: The BRISTOL HOTEL.--
div.p: Mr. Bauer, the manager of the Briswi Holei, Cairo, bas taken over tuu luase of this popular resurt of visitors t the Capital direct from the proprietors of the builuuy. Mr. Bauer, who has already greaty improved this hotel, mtulids to rearrange tue whule builuing and rejuruish it anew, 80 that il will be in every respect one of the most upw-date establishments of tue kind in the Capital. This news will be received with great pleasury by the onents of the Bristol Hotel, wuch has been so excellently managed for some time past by Mr. Bauer.

div.p: Tuat excellent Greek benevolent society, the Poiloptuchos of Alexaridris, is giving its annual grand "Vegione" at thu Zizinia Theatre next Saturday evening under the patronage of the collowing ladies ut the committee : Mesdames A. Pangulos (president p. i.), C. Sitadmo vice-presiueut), Virginie Emm. Benachi (treasurer), 0. M. Salvago, A. C. Zervudaclit, M. Sinaudino, G. C. Zervudachi, Const. Chyremni, N. Tsamis, F. div.head: OFFICIAL SALARIES.-
div.p: The question of the proportions that should prevait between official salaries and the recent abnormal rise in price of all the necessities of life in Egypt is to be seriously considered by the Government, which has approved of the institution of a committee charged with the study of the situation with a view to improvement. This committee, which will be presided over by Mr. Macbell, the Advisur to the Minietry of the Interior, will consist of the Director-General of the Accounts Department to the Ministry of Finance, the Director-General of Customs, and the Direotor. General of the Survey Department,

div.head:
CAIRO AGRICULTURAL SHOW.
LIST OF PRIZE WINNERS.
div.p: Owing to the bad cotton season of 1904, 1 fewer 1st prizes have been given this year than in recent exbibitions, but the average of the exhibits is very fair notwithstanding, and there are some interesting features which deserve special notice. The Daira Sanieh have obtained two special 1st prizes, one for Ashmouni cotton grown as far south as Erment, ! and one for excellent Afifi grown at the same place. The better known varieties of cotton, Jannovich, Afifi, Ashmouni, Alume, are well represented, and of the new and less known varieties there is an excellent show of Nubari and a beautiful example of Charara from Me.. noufieh, with excellent samples of Voltos and Kerki.
The grain exhibits are decidedly good, the | Princesses Nimet and Anineh Hanem, Omar

Bey Sultan, Priuce Omar Pasha Toussoun, Riaz Pasha, Boghios Pasha Nubar, and A. Zeid Bey Tautawi being prominent among the prize winners. The Kom Ombo Company's exbibit deserves special mention, as it includes wheat harvested on the 4th inst, and barley harvested on the 15th January, 1905 L

Some interesting pot experiments with various fertilisers are well worth notice, while among the animals and poultry exhibited, Prince Omar l'æ ha Toussuun's specimens are particularly five. The mats and straw work exhibited are very prettily designed and look durable. The following are the prize-winners for cereals :Class.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: The Khedive, after attending KourbanBeyram prayers yesterday morning at Koubbeh Mosque, proceeded to Abdeen Palace to hold the Kourban-Beyram reception, which was nutnerously attended.
On Monday the Khedive gave audience to Sheikh Mohamed Abdou, Grand Moufti of B:ypt, who gave a description to his Highness of his recent trip to the Sudan.

div.head: THE LATE E. J. MANUK.
div.p: The funeral of the late Mr. E. J. Manuk, whose sudden death on Sunday came as a shock to the many friends he possessed in Cairo, took place on Monday afternoon, amidst a large
concourse of people. The chief mourner was | the deceased's brother, Mr. E C. Manuk, of

Alexandria, and the mortal remains of the | deceased were followed to their last resting J place by everyone distinguished in the world of finance and of commerce, of which Mr. Mamuk was a prominent member. There was an iminense quantity of wreaths. The burial service was held at St. Joseph's Church,
Ismailia, and the interment took place in 1 & temporary vault in the Latin cemetery. A number of shops on the line of ronte of the fa neral were closed as a sign of respeot for the deceased.

div.head: THE ROYAL VISIT. A TRIP TO KARNAK.

div.p: The Duke and Duchess of Connaught are expected to reach Luxor tomorrow. They will remain at Luxor till Thursday. Instructions had been issued by the Ministry of the Interior to the Moudir to proceed to Luxor in order I to be in attendance on the Doke during his stay there. The Moudir, accompanied by the Police Commandant, is leaving at noon for Luxor. I learn that the railway authorities have arranged to send a special train from Cairo to Luxor on Wednesday for the purpose of conveying the Royal party back to Cairo.

The Duke and Duchess of Connaught spent last night at Arment and arrived here this morning at 10 o'clock. All the consular agents and the moudirieh officials were waiting at the lauding-stage to welcome the Royal visitors. The two Princesses landed first and rode to ] Karnak, one og horseback and the other on a donkey. The Duchess and inite followed later, and afterwards the Duke, with General Sir J. Maxwell. All went on donkeys. The party returned about noon, and the Duke and Duchess went on board their yacht after a short walk on the quay, while the Princesses went on a visit to the town.

The Duke and Duchess of Connaught changed their landing-stage from the Anglo-American Company's platform to a landing-stage at Karnak, which the Government had already prepared for them, and which, I suppose, faci. litated their visit to the ruins. About 3 p.m. they went to visit the Tombs of the Kings, where they took tea.

div.head: THE EX-EMPRESS EUGENIE.
div.p: The ex-Empress Eugenie and suite arrived here this afternoon about 4 o'clock from Cairo in a dababieh. The distinguished lady landed at about five and paid a short visit to Luxor Temple, afterwardsproceeding to the Luxor Hotel, where she took tea and perused the latest telegrams.

div.head: PRINCE OF SWEDEN'S VISIT.
div.p: H. R. H. Prince Gustavus Adolphus of Sweden and Norway is paying a visit to Luxor incognito on a private dababieh. Yesterday he dined at the Luxor Hotel, and to-day he has been visiting some antiquity shops and merchants. Two plain-clothes policemen sre keeping watch over him.

div.head: LORD CROMER'S TRIP.
div.p: Lord and Lady Cromer, accompanied by Lady Beatrice Thynne, arrived here this morning on their stram dahabieh. The distinguished party stopped here for about two hours, daring which time Lady Cromer visited Luxor Temple. They afterwards proceeded to Assouan.

div.head: SUPREME CONSULAR COURT.
div.p: Mr. Pigott, the acting Chief Justice of His Majesty's Supreme Consular Court for the Dominions of the Sublime Ottoman Porte, will arrive here on Saturday next from Constantinople and will proceed direct to Cairo.
There are no cases down for hearing at Alexandria.

div.head: EXCAVATIONS ON THE CANAL
div.p: At the last meeting of the Academy of Inscriptions and Belles lettres of Paris it was announced that the board of the Suez Canal Company had decided to commence archæological excavations in the region traversed by the Saez Canal. The work will be enfanted to M. Clédat, of the Cairo Archäological Institnte, and the excavations will begin at Tel el-Herr.

div.head: TYROL
div.p: Weissenstein Castle 3410 . ft. First-class private hotel near Windisch-Matrei; Station, Liens (reached from Venice or Trieste). Bracing air. Good Mountaineering centre. Tennis Pishing. Best June, September. Apply Proprietan

div.head:
GEN. STOESSEL AT PORT SAID.
DEPARTURE FOR RUSSIA.

div.p: The Messageries Maritimes mil steamer "Australien," having General Swessel, Mme. Stoessel, and 498 officers and men of the Port Arthur garrison on board, artived at Saen at 9 o'cloek this morning, en rute for Port Said, where they will embark on board the Roskian steamer "Saint Nicolas" for Odessa. .
The "Australien" entered the Canal at 1.30 this afternoon.
The Messageries steamer "Australien," with General and Mme. Stoensel and the officers and men accompanying him, is nowin the Canal and is due at Port Said early to-morrow morning.
The "Saint Nicolas" reached bere from Odessa yesterday, and is now awaiting their arrival
E: General Stoessel transhipped from the. S.S. "Anstralien" to the 8.8. "St. Nicolas" at 9.30 a.m. to day. The latter steamer leaves for Theodosia at 3 o'dlock this afternoon.

div.head: ANOTHER TURBINE STEAMER.
div.p: Another new tarbine steamer, the "Lanka” (Capt. Wilson), arrived at Port Said this morning bound for Colombo. She was built by Messrs. Denny and Co., of Glasgow, for the British India Steam Navigation Company. Her speed from Glasgow, which she left on the 4th inst., has averaged 147 knots, but she is capable of 19. She has accommodation for 48 first-class passengers, and will probably run between Calentta and Rangoon.

div.head: THE "C. O. D.” SYSTEM.
div.p: We understand that the suggestions contained in our leading article of Thursday last bave been received with a considerable amount of favor by the authorities, and that steps will be taken to introduce the cash-on-delivery system of the postal service between Egypt and the Sudan.
We have good reason to believe, too, that the opposition to the establishment of the system between Egypt and England is likely to be overcome.

div.head: SMUGGLING AT ALEXANDRIA.
div.p: The Coastguards at Alexandria have been very busy the last few days in seizing contraband goods in the shape of firearms, hashish, ammunition, powder, etc.
On Sunday morning, 143 kilos of hashishi was seized near the landing-stage inside the enclosure of the Ports and Lighthouses Ad. ministration.

Yesterday, on searching the Italian S.S. "Nina," the Coastguards found two large portmanteaux, containing 70 kilos of hashish, | and also the following treasure trove : 101 breech-loading rifles of all kinds, including Martini-Henry, Chassepot, and Gras, 11 revolvers, some of them exquisitely mounted with ivory handles, 1,490 ball (rifle) cartridges, 1,474 ball (revolver) cartridges, 250,000 per cussion caps for Arab sporting guns, 19 tins of sporting powder, and 4,900 choice Havana cigars.
The night previous to this haul the smugglers had kept the Coastguards baay in the harbour and there were some exciting chases.

It is surmised that the rifles and ammunition were intended for the Tripoli coast, where the vessel would land them on her return voyage. The arms are too unwieldly. to be landed at Alexandria without detection. This is the largest haul of valuable contraband that has been made at Alexandria this year.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The Ellerman S.S. "Sardinia," now on the berth for Liverpool, will sail for that port on Sanday.

div.p: Again, a considerable datoe of annogunos to residents and visitors are the short hours that the post office is open auch day, it seine nothing short of a publio scandal that it shoäld be closed at all during the day. div.head: THE RACES.
div.p: The races instituted by the Holocan Sporting Club, last year, have 'proved great Success this season, the attendance at anch of the first two meetings has been all that dould be desired, and there is every prospect of another good day at the meeting to be held next Friday.

div.head: GOLFING..
div.p: The Helouan Golf Club is again proving great attraction to visitors, the weekly com, petitions being keonly contested. The Nango. vich Company, by whom the links are maintrained, have generously doubled the start this season, and in consequence the links, hava been greatly improved and have never beda in better order.

div.head: CHRONIQUE JUDICIAIRE
div.p: UN RAID AU MARIOUT

Trois bédouins, dont l'un était gaffir et les deux autres locataires de Moussa Maatouk, vendirent il y a quelque temps à Bolonachi les terrains de leur propriétaire. Un hodget en règle fut rédigé par le Gouvernement Egyptien. Le contrat de vente, signé par le gaffir et les deux locataires, et fabriqué comme tant d'autres dans des circonstances analogues fut régu lièrement transcrit. On sait qu'ici, comme en tous pays latins, la transcription se borne à un simple paiement des droits, sans être soumise aux investigations qui sont de rigueur dans les pays où le système Torrens a été adopté. Les transactions immobilières obtiennent done en Egypte, par le seul fait de leur transcription, la publicité requise, sans jamais acquérir, pourtant, force probante.

L'acte de vente enfin signé et dûment transcrit, il restait à M. Bolanachi de prendre possession des terrains. Il organisa un raid sur la propriété de Moussa Maatouk à l'aide d'une bande de bédouins. Une vingtaine de tentes furent plantées çà et là. Le légitime proprié taire, ne disposant pas de forces suffisantes pour faire respecter ses droits, eut recours à la police qui mit en fuite les agresseurs.

Alors commença la procédure. M. Bolanachi et ses vendeurs assignèrent M. Maatouk par devant le tribunal de justice sommaire et demandèrent à être réintégrés dans leur possessions interrompue de 1,725 teddans. Ils of frirent de prouver comme d'ordinaire qu'ils possédaient paisiblement et de temps immé morial les terrains en litige. Cette preuve leur fut d'autant plus facile qu'ils avaient pour témoins des compères de la même tribu et vivant des mêmes expédients.

Bien que M. Maatouk ait fait la preuve contraire, M. Bolonachi obtint gain de cause. Maatouk vient naturellement de faire appel de ce premier jugement. Il prétend que l'action en réintégrande, intentée par Bolonachi, manque absolument de base, son intrusion sur les terrains litigieux, qui a duré seulement quelques jours, ne pouvant être assimilée à la détention paisible et publique, requise en pareil cas.

div.head: CHRONIQUE THEATRALE
div.p: THEATRE ZIZINIA
LES TROIS ANABAPTISTES
Le public Alexandrin, si difficile à émouvoir d'ordinaire, s'est abandonné hier au Zizinia à une franche gaieté. On jouait Les Trois Anabaptistes, comédie de M.M. A. Bisson et B. Tarique.

Le rôle comique de Mattre Virginie a été tenu de façon magistrale par Mme Pauline Patry, surtout dans la scène du troisième acto ot sa mimique désopilante a secoué toute la salle d'un éclat de rire général. Très réussi également M. Cooper dans le rôle de Lepailleur où il se trouvait d'ailleurs dans son élément. M, Laurent manque parfois d'aisance et de haturel dans ses rôles. Son interprétation de Radiguais s'en est un peu ressentie. M. Duboco a été comme d'habitude d'une indifférence qui lui sied à merveille en d'autres occasions, mais qui dans le rôle d'Anatole Guillemard ne lui allait pas du tout. Bien que Mme Lelières arrive rarement à passionner son public, elle se tire assez bien des rôles qui ne demandent pas d'animation, comme c'était le cas dans Mme Radiguais. Mile Georgette Loyer promet comme débutante. Elle l'a bien montré dans le Petit Lord et hier soir dans Mme Lepailleur. M. Diamand a été un président fort convenable; comme acteur, entendons-nous. Les autres roles sont trop. effacés pour mériter une mention. Certains d'entre eux ont été d'ailleurs absolument ratés, tel celui de Gilbert.
Malgré tout la pièce a plu à tout le monde, ce qui montre bien que le choix des représentations doit être la principale préoccupation du directeur.

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: (Aujourd'hui à midi et demie). Nous avons eu aujourd'hui la journée la plus brillante depuis le commencement de l'année. La hausse est générale et les transactions énor mes. sur les principales valeurs. On attribue cette amélioration à l'activité de la demande locale et à l'excellente tenue des marchés européens.

ta La Banque Nationale atteint 26 15/16 acheteurs, l'Agricole 11 3/4 vendeurs, la Daïra 24 3/8 acheteurs, les Markets 25/3 acheteurs, la Salt and Soda 41/9 vendeurs, l'Anglo American Nile 5 7/8 vendeurs et la Delta Light 14 9/16 acheteurs, sans parler de plusieurs autres va leurs qui sont également en hausse.
Les affaires ont été surtout nombreuses en Banques Nationale et Agricole, en Daira, ent Delta et en Markets; mais l'animation a gagné presque toute la cote.

Toute somme dont le paiement est retardé portera de plein droit intérêts en faveur de la Société au taux de 7% l'an, à compter du jour de l'exigibilité, sans aucune demande en justice. (Art. 7 des Statuts). 25438-3-2
Municipalité d'Alexandrie
AVIS
La Municipalité met en adjudication les travaux de dallage des rues Moussaferkana, El Helal et Sidi Daoud, et de deux ruelles près du Mawazini.
Le cautionnement est fixé à LE. 40.
Le cahier des charges est déposé au bureau de la Voirie où il peut être consulté par les intéressés tous les jours de 9 h. à midi, les jours fériés exceptés.
Les offres devront être adressées sous pli ca cheté à Monsieur l'Administrateur de la Municipalité avant le 28 courant.
Elles pourront également être déposées en séance de la Délégation le même jour à 5h.p.m. L'enveloppe devra potter en outre la mention: "Soumission pour dallage rues Moussaferkana etc."

Le cautionnement ou le reçu d'une Banque, d'après les conditions du cahier des charges, devra être remis au Service de la Comptabilité avant l'ouverture des offres et au plus tard le 28 février à midi.
L'Administrateur, (Signé) W. P. CHATAWAY Alexandrie, le 11 février 1905. 25435-3-2

div.head: AVIS
div.p: Le Mardi 21 février courant de 11 h. a.m. à 1 h. p.m. et de 3h. au coucher du soleil, la Municipalité procèdera à la vente aux enchères publiques près des cimetières européens, sis à la Porte Kosette, d'une quantité de 2000 m3. environ des pierres extraites des terrains des fortifications divisée en lots de 40 à 100 m3.

Les acheteurs devront payer le droit d'enchère de 1% et déposer le 10% de la valeur de la marchandise achetée au moment de la vente et effectuer le paiement intégral à la Caisse Municipale le lendemain du jour de l'adjudication.
Ils auront à supporter les droits de carrière au profit de la Ville et devront enlever les pierres achetées dans un délai de dix jours, sous peine de folle enchère pour compte de l'adjudicataire.
L'Administrateur, (Signé) W. P. CHATAWAY Alexandrie, le 11 février 1905.

div.head: ARMY AND NAVY
div.p: (FROM OUR CORRESPONDENT).
London, February 4.

The programme of reliefs for the trooping season of 1905-06, just issued, shows that the 2nd Battalion Rifle Brigade, now at Khartoum, will move to India, and will be replaced by the 2nd Battalion Dublin Fusiliers, now in Malta. That is the only change to be made in the infantry brigade.

The Royal Garrison Artillery reliefs have not yet been issued, but to-day I received private intelligence from Bertauda to the effect that No. 2 Company R.G.A. has been ordered to embark there to-morrow for Southampton, where it will be transhipped to the S.S. "Dilwara" en voyage for Alexandria. No. 2 Company is commanded by Major R. Percy-Smith and the other officers are: Captains W. N. Gordon, H. R. Brancker, and Lieutenants N. C. S. Simpson, F. W. Willis, C. H. M. Furnell, and G. Grylls.
Major and Brevet Lieutenant Colonel G. F. W. St. John, late commanding the Royal Artillery in Egypt, has been formally appointed brigade major for, R. A. at "Gib."

The five battalions of the Royal Garrison Regiment will be broken up on the 1st April. Officers who elect to do so may go on retired pay, and the remainder will be transferred to other regiments. The rank and file will be generously dealt with in the matter of bounty and inducements to settle down in South Africa, where the 1st, 2nd, 3rd, and 4th Bat talions are, or Canada, where the 5th Battalion is stationed. Men of 14 years' (or over) service will be discharged on a modified pension.
The smart girdle lately issued to the R.F.A. is only to be worn on home service. Gunners going abroad will not be served out with it.
The 1st Battalion, Royal Inniskilling Fusiliers will move from Derry and Enniskillen to Belfast in the coming trooping season.

The King will inspect H.M.S. "Drake"- flagship of Prince Louis of Battenberg, commanding the Second Cruiser Squadron-about the end of this month, prior to the squadron leaving England for an extended cruise in North and South American waters. As already announced in these notes, the cruise of this powerful 24-knot squadron is for the purpose of letting some of the more distant foreign nations see that "britanuis rules the waves" is no empty boast.

RS. COL. E. J. GRESHAM, Treasurer Daughters of the Confederacy, and President Herndon Village Inprovement Society, writes the following letter from Herndon, Fairfax county, Virginia:

Herndon, Va. The Peruna Medicine Co., Columbus, O.: Gentlemen-"I cannot speak too highly of the value of Peruna. I believe that I owe my life to its wonderful merits. I suffered with catarrh of the head and lungs in its worst form, until the doctors fairly gave me up, and I despaired of ever getting well again.
"I noticed your advertisement and the splendid testimonials given by people who had been cured by Peruna, and de termined to try a bottle. I felt but little
better, but used a second and a third bottle and kept on improving slowly.
"It took six bottles to cure me, but they were worth a king's ransom to me. I talk Peruna to all my friends and am a true believer in its worth."
Mrs. Col. E. J. Gresham.

TANTAH. SHEBIN-EL-KOM. Shebin-el-Kom, Saturday.

In spite of rain and very cold weather, the above teams met on Shebin School playground yesterday afternoon. Among those who were present were H.B. the Moudir, the wekil, the mamour, the judge, the two doctors of the province, the sanitary inspector, Rev. W. T. Fairman, the head of the English school, Mr. Hewett, the agent of the National Bank's branch here, and other notables. The result of the game was unfortunate for Shebin. They were the losers, having failed to secure a single goal against Tantah's four.
LAWN TENNIS TOURNAMENT.
The annual lawn tennis tournament at the K.S.C., Cairo, will be held on March 13 and tollowing days. Further particulars will be announced later.

div.head: CONSTANTINIDI SUIT.
div.p: WIFE'S APPEAL.

The Constantinidiauit came before the London Divorce Court again last week. Mr. Barnard applied for a stay of execution from a judg ment of Sir Francis Jeune, given in December last on an application of the husband for a variation of the marriage settlement in his favor. The President then made an order directing the trustees of the settlements to pay over large sums to the husband, and the application was now for a stay of execution pending an appeal by the wife.
The judge granted the application..

div.head: ABBAS HELMY THEATRE.
div.p: CARMEN.

Another large and fashionable audience assembled on Monday evening at the Abbas Helmy Theatre to witness the first production by the present company of Carmen, that delightful single gem left for our enjoyment, and possibly our moralising, by Bizet that story, now so familiar, of a tickle maiden, disappointed love, and the consequent tragical overthrow of the hopes and aspirations of all concerned. The great attraction of the evening was the appearance in the title role of Signora Gemma Beltincioni, so justly celebrated for her interpre tation of the character. Carmen does not lend much scope to the artiste for brilliant vocalisation, but abundant opportunites are afforded for the display of histrionio ability, and not one of these was missed by Signora Bellincioni, who impersonated the character of the wanton flirt to the life. It is scarcely necessary to add that her various vocal numbers were rendered with that care and skill now so well known to Alexandrians, and those present on Monday were not slow in showing their appreciation of her splendid performance, and on every possible occasion applauded frantically this truly distinguished artiste. Signora Bellincioni was very ably supported by Signor Pagani, who was in excellent voice; his performance throughout the opera merits the highest commendation. Signor Badini was distinctly disappointing as Becamillo, and missed a fine opportunity in the famous Toreador song in his apparent anxiety to get through with it as quickly as possible. A word of praise is due to Signora Tadolini for her sympathetic impersonation of the rather thankless role of Micaela. The other characters were in good hands and the chorus well up to their work. The staging of the opera was exceptionally good, and the orchestra did its work well under the able bâton of Siguor Donizetti, who deserves great credit.
This evening, Il Barbiere di Siviglia will be produced, with Signora Svicher, and to-morrow: evening Signora Beltincioni will appear in Cavalleria Rusticana, which will be preceded by I Pagliacci.
